discourse_list.title: Are all circulating DAI coins created / minted from vaults?

content.content: I am trying to understand this a little bit, apologies if its been asked before, DAI is proving to be the stable-coin role model with minimal peg volatility but if its circulating supply is limited to pledging other coins (i.e. ETH, BTC) wouldn’t that hurt scalability?
Thanks for the response. What others ways are there to mint DAI? What is backing those DAI?
I feel like maybe you haven’t just Googled it… But the main way is the PSM. Anyone can swap 1 USDC for 1 DAI or vice versa. In fact, the majority of DAI come from this

Ok, what is an example of why someone would swap USDC for DAI or viceversa? They are both USD pegged stablecoins in the ETH network. I have googled but was confused and thought others might struggle with this concept and probably this community might be better able to explain.
Good one. This bear market got you in a mood I guess. Just asked a couple of questions… jeez
TRUEMAKER:  if its circulating supply is limited to pledging other coins (i.e. ETH, BTC) wouldn’t that hurt scalability?   Other coins can represent anything, though. Including real world assets.

TRUEMAKER:  Thanks for the response. What others ways are there to mint DAI? What is backing those DAI?   Hi @TRUEMAKER, thanks for these good questions. There are some helpful Maker sources around, particularly at makerburn.com (ft. fun charts) and https://docs.makerdao.com/. Re: your questions about DAI, you might like these posts from @Artem_Gordon about DAI, namely: State of DAI | June 7 - 13, 2022 That post has some great info about how the existing DAI supply has been generated (these numbers will have changed in the last week, though, as a small caveat):  image1380×884 62.8 KB

The answer is pretty simple…sometimes people might just want to hold DAI over USDC. Ask yourself…why do people hold USDC and not just keep things in USD?  Currently the USDC market cap is 56B as opposed to the 6.8B DAI has.  So USDC is obviously still more desired but just as there are applications that holding USDC over USD enables (maybe as simple as trading different crypto assets), there are applications that DAI can be used for and there are overlaps between the two coins.  So at the end of the day it just comes down to trust (risk) and reward.  Some stablecoins out there yield 30%…but they’re not trusted.  DAI is a very trusted coin in the defi space.  But you don’t really get much for holding it right now.  But say the DSR was set to the treasury rate and DAI holders could passively get part of treasury bond returns just by holding DAI?  Well, I would bet some of that USDC that returns nothing would flow to DAI.  Maybe some USD too!  But it’s all a competition because nothing prevents USDC from offering that rate as well. So how else could we differentiate DAI without compromising its safety or MKR’s solvency?  That’s the trillion dollar question we try to answer every day.
Thank you, I was overthinking it a little bit! I get your point around competing stablecoin demand based on preference, potential rate of return (i.e. interest rate) and application usage.
